messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: Alan, T-, Milt, Peter, and John, Thanks for the replies. Alan s on the Owari Kinko was the only one that had not crossed my mind yet. I do not have the Owari
messages.messageBody:
Alan, T-, Milt, Peter, and John,

Thanks for the replies. Alan's on the Owari Kinko was
the only one that had not crossed my mind yet. I do
not have the Owari book he mentioned, so Pete will
hafta comment on that.

Tsuba #1: Work is definitely better than what I know
as Waki Goto. But I came across pieces that reminded
me of it. They were described as "'Kaga Waki Goto".

Tsuba #2: This is the better tsuba of the two. The
sakudo is a beautiful ink color and the piece is
rather heavy. The condition is extremely good. The
shakudo is all a high polish luster. Not nanako. The
quality of the work does remind me of the better Kaga
I have seen. The gold inlay is 99% there, but missing
one tiny spot that helps to reveal that the channels
and the gold inlay are rather deep.
This is the one that has me stumped the most.
Somehow doesn't feel like Kaga work. The shape? The
execution of some of the curves & lines?
I definitely have a lot to learn.

Thank you for the help. If someone can expand on Owari
kinko, I'd like to know more about this work.

Curran
C^3

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: I also missed part of the description (thinking these were iron plate) but kinko, well that makes a big difference. No. 8 does make me think Omori work. Other
messages.messageBody:
I also missed part of the description (thinking these were iron plate) but kinko, well that makes a big difference. No. 8 does make me think Omori work. Other than that, with what looks like heavy gold overlay, I'm not sure where I'd go from there. (I've a pair of same motif menuki that I've had for decades, and still scratching my head over.)

This would seem to be Kaga work based on the flat inlay "fret" work but honestly, the tsuba "feels" like something made by Norisuke, particularly the way the flowers are represented. I suspect this is possibly his work and if so, quite a nice example. Wild guess?

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Pete, It,s not Ikkodo (一光堂), it is 興善寺 and covers various types of tsuba including some that I would say were pure Kaga-zogan, look in the Owari
messages.messageBody:
Hi Pete,
It,s not Ikkodo (一光堂), it is 興善寺 and covers various types of tsuba including some that I would say were pure Kaga-zogan, look in the Owari book at the back for examples.
Alan


----- Original Message -----
From: klepet33319
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, March 30, 2006 1:12 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei


Hi Alan -- Would that be the same as Owari Ikko-do? There is a tsuba
on Tokugawa (tsuba page one bottom) which has that same look and goes
by that description. I had not heard that term before.
Hope all is well.
Pete Klein
http://www.sanmei.com/shop_e/enter.html

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: I think the first tsuba may be Owari kinko, it has a feeling of early Nagoya work when the quality was high. The second might also be Owari kinko of the type
messages.messageBody:
I think the first tsuba may be Owari kinko, it has a feeling of early Nagoya work when the quality was high. The second might also be Owari kinko of the type called 'Kozenji', I am not sure what this means as it seems to be a catchall term, is the plate nanako struck over the gold lightning pattern? Perhaps Jim could help on these.
Alan
----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, March 30, 2006 3:43 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei


List,

I have 2 tsuba that I would like opinions about.

Tsuba #1: Shishi

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/ff0b?b=8

Tsuba #2: Unknown

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/ff0b?b=9
_____________________________________________________

Both photos are in my YahooGroups folder. Please
ignore the spots of high red. I'm still experimenting
with photography and did not clean these images at
all.

The shishi tsuba is nice. The nanako is very good and
interesting in that it changes pattern on the sections
with the shi-shi. My hesitation is that the general
work is very good but not Goto grade. How else might
this one be attributed?

The second tsuba is solid shakudo of excellent color
and very heavy. The carving is lush and extremely
detailed. Despite the thickness of the piece and the
carving, everything has a smooth roundedness to it so
that there are no obtruding edges.

Any help appreciated. I'd like to figure these out as
much as possible before I consider whether to submit
to shinsa.

Thanks,

Curran



__________________________________________________

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: CC, I like Waki-goto for the shishi mid to late Edo, unusual presentation, almost modern, large hitsu and think they were filled with gold from the start.
messages.messageBody:
CC,
I like Waki-goto for the shishi mid to late Edo, unusual
presentation, almost modern, large hitsu and think they were filled
with gold from the start. maybe it is the photo but the shishi do not
look to be "well drawn", a very cool tsuba though.
I will posit Kaga for the other as well given the inlay and all the
flowers and stuff, not a workingmans tsuba, IMHO. Something made for
sale to the fashion conscious public...
=t

messages.msgSnippet: On Mar 29, 2006, at 8:37 PM, bungotakadasword wrote: #1........ not nanako ground, mumei........so probably not Ishiguro school  . Doesn t look/feel like a
messages.messageBody:
On Mar 29, 2006, at 8:37 PM, bungotakadasword wrote:
#1........ not nanako ground, mumei........so probably not Ishiguro
school .
Doesn't look/feel like a Goto even though the quality is wayyyyyy up
there.
I am guessing a/ Omori , b/ Yanogawa, c/ Kyo-kinko ( edo/Mito
kinko ), the most likely shinsa attribution .....in that order

#2..........a/ Higo, b/ Kaga, c/ Kensho Shoami........ in that order

milt

Use a shotgun Milt, you're bound to hit something...
-t

messages.subject: Re: 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, I am not a tousougu person but both are nice tsuba. The first srikes me as Nara kinko, everything fits the profile. The second Shouami but might fit
messages.messageBody:
Curran, I am not a tousougu person but both are nice tsuba. The
first srikes me as Nara kinko, everything fits the profile. The
second Shouami but might fit Kaga school in Mino style. The key fret
design is familiar and doesn't it lead to something? connected to
Kaga. John

messages.subject: 2 new Tsuba to ask about / Kantei
messages.msgSnippet: List, I have 2 tsuba that I would like opinions about. Tsuba #1:    Shishi http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/ff0b?b=8 Tsuba #2:
messages.messageBody:
List,

I have 2 tsuba that I would like opinions about.

Tsuba #1: Shishi

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/ff0b?b=8

Tsuba #2: Unknown

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/view/ff0b?b=9
_____________________________________________________

Both photos are in my YahooGroups folder. Please
ignore the spots of high red. I'm still experimenting
with photography and did not clean these images at
all.

The shishi tsuba is nice. The nanako is very good and
interesting in that it changes pattern on the sections
with the shi-shi. My hesitation is that the general
work is very good but not Goto grade. How else might
this one be attributed?

The second tsuba is solid shakudo of excellent color
and very heavy. The carving is lush and extremely
detailed. Despite the thickness of the piece and the
carving, everything has a smooth roundedness to it so
that there are no obtruding edges.

Any help appreciated. I'd like to figure these out as
much as possible before I consider whether to submit
to shinsa.

Thanks,

Curran
